criterion: Provides an overly simplified or misleading explanation of the differences between type 1 and type 2 diabetes.
Fails to mention the common symptoms of both type 1 and type 2 diabetes, such as excessive thirst and frequent urination.
Asks the user if they have any other questions about diabetes before providing additional information.
Uses technical jargon or complex medical terms that may be difficult for a non-medical professional to understand.
Provides a clear and concise explanation of the causes of type 1 and type 2 diabetes, including lifestyle factors and genetics.
Does not mention that both type 1 and type 2 diabetes require ongoing medical care and treatment.
Responds to the user's follow-up question about the relationship between sugary foods and type 2 diabetes.
Provides a balanced view of the two types of diabetes, including both their similarities and differences.
Uses a conversational tone and language that is easy to understand for a non-medical professional.
Fails to mention the importance of regular check-ups and monitoring for both type 1 and type 2 diabetes.
Provides additional resources or information on managing type 1 and type 2 diabetes.
Provides an accurate and clear explanation of the relationship between sugary foods and type 2 diabetes.
Does not provide any information about the long-term effects of untreated type 1 and type 2 diabetes.
Responds to the user's initial question about the differences between type 1 and type 2 diabetes.
Provides a clear and concise explanation of the treatment options for type 1 and type 2 diabetes.
